newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: LME copper to test US$2,380, Chinese demand strong.
newsitem.headline: LME copper to test US$2,380, Chinese demand strong.

text.p: Three-month copper prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) will probably test resistance at US$2,380 a tonne, largely on the back of strong Chinese interest, traders said on Thursday.

"We expected three-month copper prices to stay in a range between $2,320 and $2,380 a tonne. Therefore, the next move is to go up and test the resistance level," a trader with a local brokerage firm said.
The trader said the strong bounce by copper from $2,300 a tonne late on Wednesday showed Chinese demand was still alive and constructive.
However, zinc prices were seen falling on technical factors as the trade pulled back from an overbought situation, traders said.
"The market needs some kind of adjustment period in order to gather energy for a further climb," said another local broker.
Brokers said they also expected prices to decline because the gap between $1,254 and $1,262 a tonne needed to be filled.
Zinc climbed to a 4-1/2 year high earlier in the week at more than $1,300 a tonne before sliding back to its current level. It closed on Wednesday at $1,296 a tonne.
A futures broker said the zinc market was heavily overbought with the 14-day relative strength index (RSI) for three-month zinc standing at 74.80 percent.
The market generally considers an RSI of 70 or more as overbought and 30 or less as oversold.
LME three-month aluminium was nearly unchanged in quiet Asian trade on Thursday from the previous day's London trade at $1,647/$1,651 a tonne.
